facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 434 of 1963 is an appeal from the judgment and decree dated July 22, 1960, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Appeal Suit No. 709 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTIONCiVil Appeal No. 434 of 1963. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated July 22, 1960, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Appeal Suit No. 709 of 1954. Ranganadham Chetty, A. Vedavalli and A.V. Rangam, for the appellants.

facts.text: The first respondent, Seetharamamma, is a Brahmin woman married to Ramakrishnayya, who is still alive.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent, Seetharamamma, is a Brahmin woman. She was married to one Ramakrishnayya. During the life-time of her husband she became the companycubine of one Lingayya, a Sudra by caste.

facts.text: Seetharamamma became the concubine of Lingayya, a Sudra, during her husband's lifetime.

anchor.surface_text: During the life-time of her husband she became the companycubine of one Lingayya, a Sudra by caste. From 1938 until the death of Lingayya in February, 1948, she was the permanently kept companycubine of Lingayya, and lived with him.

facts.text: From 1938 until Lingayya's death in February 1948, Seetharamamma was his permanently kept concubine and lived with him.

anchor.surface_text: From 1938 until the death of Lingayya in February, 1948, she was the permanently kept companycubine of Lingayya, and lived with him. During this period and thereafter, she preserved sexual fidelity to Lingayya.

facts.text: Seetharamamma preserved sexual fidelity to Lingayya during his lifetime and thereafter.

anchor.surface_text: During this period and thereafter, she preserved sexual fidelity to Lingayya. The second, third and fourth respondents are the sons of the first respondent by Lingayya.

facts.text: Second, third and fourth respondents are sons of Seetharamamma by Lingayya.

anchor.surface_text: The second, third and fourth respondents are the sons of the first respondent by Lingayya. The husband of the first respondent is still alive. The appellants are the brothers and brothers sons of Lingayya.

facts.text: Appellants are brothers and brother's sons of Lingayya.

anchor.surface_text: The husband of the first respondent is still alive. The appellants are the brothers and brothers sons of Lingayya. Lingayya was separate in estate from his brothers and brothers sons.

facts.text: Lingayya was separate in estate from his brothers and brother's sons.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are the brothers and brothers sons of Lingayya. Lingayya was separate in estate from his brothers and brothers sons. The parties are residents of Choragudi, Bapatla, number in Andhra Pradesh and governed by the Mitakshara school of Hindu law.

facts.text: Parties are residents of Choragudi, Bapatla, Andhra Pradesh and governed by Mitakshara school of Hindu law.

anchor.surface_text: Lingayya was separate in estate from his brothers and brothers sons. The parties are residents of Choragudi, Bapatla, number in Andhra Pradesh and governed by the Mitakshara school of Hindu law. In the plaint, as originally filed, the respondents claimed that they were exclusively entitled to the estate left by Lingayya.

facts.text: Respondents originally claimed exclusive entitlement to Lingayya's estate in the plaint.

anchor.surface_text: In the plaint, as originally filed, the respondents claimed that they were exclusively entitled to the estate left by Lingayya. The Subordinate Judge and the High Court found that as the first respondent was and companytinued to be a married woman while she lived with Lingayya and bore him children,

facts.text: Subordinate Judge originally dismissed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: the children born of the union were number his legitimate sons, number were they Dasiputras and as such entitled to his properties. The suit was originally dismissed by the Subordinate Judge, but on appeal, the High Court gave the respondents leave to amend the plaint

facts.text: High Court allowed amendment of plaint for maintenance claim and remanded the suit.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was originally dismissed by the Subordinate Judge, but on appeal, the High Court gave the respondents leave to amend the plaint by making suitable averments for the award of maintenance, and remanded the suit for trial on the question of maintenance.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge decreed respondents' maintenance claim on September 20, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: At the subsequent trial on the amended plaint, the Subordinate Judge decreed the respondents claim for maintenance and companysequential reliefs and awarded to them maintenance during their lifetime out of the estate of Lingayya. The Subordinate Judge passed his decree on September 20, 1954.

facts.text: Hindu Adoptions and Maintenance Act, 1956 came into force during pendency of appeal before High Court.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the appeal preferred by the appellants before the High Court, the Hindu Adoptions and Maintenance Act of 1956  hereinafter referred to as the Act  came into force.

facts.text: High Court referred appeal to Full Bench due to importance of questions.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the importance of these questions, the appeal was referred to a Full Bench of the High Court.

facts.text: High Court held Act applies only to estates of Hindus dying after commencement.

anchor.surface_text: On the first question the High Court held that the relevant provisions of the Act applied only to the estates of Hindus dying after the companymencement of the Act,

facts.text: High Court held first respondent was Avaruddha Stree entitled to maintenance despite husband alive and adulterous connection.

anchor.surface_text: On the second question, the High Court held that the first respondent was an Avaruddha Stree of Lingayya, and was entitled to maintenance from his estate, though her husband was alive and the companynection with Lingayya was adulterous.

facts.text: Appellants contend respondents not entitled to maintenance pre-Act as not Dasi/Dasiputras, point concluded by previous HC judgment.

anchor.surface_text: From 1938 until the death of Lingayya in February, 1948, she was the permanently kept companycubine of Lingayya, and lived with him. During this period and thereafter, she preserved sexual fidelity to Lingayya.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the respondents were entitled to maintenance during their lives out of the estate of Lingayya under the Hindu law as it stored in 1948, when Lingayya died, in December 1949, when the suit was instituted

facts.text: Supreme Court holds respondents entitled to lifetime maintenance out of Lingayya's estate under pre-1956 Hindu law.

anchor.surface_text: Under the Hindu law, as it stood prior to the companymencement of the Act, the first, second and third respondents were, therefore, entitled to maintenance during their lifetime, out of the estate of Lingayya.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Hindu Adoptions and Maintenance Act 1956 does not affect vested maintenance rights from Lingayya's death.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the appeal preferred by the appellants before the High Court, the Hindu Adoptions and Maintenance Act of 1956  hereinafter referred to as the Act  came into force.

concepts.interpretation: Not retrospective; does not affect vested maintenance rights arising before commencement from death under prior Hindu law

anchor.surface_text: Section 4 of the Act is as follows Save as otherwise expressly provided in this Act,- a  any text, rule or interpretation of Hindu law or any custom or usage as part of that law in force immediately before the commencement of this Act shall cease to have effect

concepts.interpretation: Prior Hindu law ceases for matters provided in Act but respects vested rights
